contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Boxer | name = Tommy Loughran | nationality = American | realname = Thomas Loughran | nickname = Phantom of Philly | weight = [[Light Heavyweight]] | height = {{convert|5|ft|11+1/2|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | reach = {{convert|73|in|cm|abbr=on}} | birth_date = {{birth date|1902|11|29|mf=y}} | death_date= {{death date and age|1982|7|7|1902|11|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | death_place= [[Altoona, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | home = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | style = Orthodox | total = 175 | wins = 96 | KO = 17 | losses = 24 | draws = 9 | no decisions = 45 | no contest = 1 }} '''Thomas Patrick Loughran''' (November 29, 1902 â€“ July 7, 1982) was an [[United States|American]] professional boxer and the former [[light heavyweight]] [[boxing]] champion of the world. Loughran's effective use of coordinated foot work, sound defense and swift, accurate counter punching is now regarded as a precursor to the techniques practiced in modern boxing. Loughran fought many middleweight, light heavyweight, and heavyweight champions in his career, including [[Gene Tunney]], [[Jack Sharkey]] and [[Georges Carpentier]]. Loughran even achieved a Newspaper Decision over fistic phenom [[Harry Greb]]. Loughran was but 19 years old when he first met Greb. As a light heavyweight, he defeated two future world heavyweight champions: [[Max Baer (boxer)|Max Baer]] and [[James J. Braddock]]. Loughran finally fought [[Primo Carnera]] for the heavyweight title but lost a decision. While Loughran is remembered among boxing's elite, his career was marred by his fragile hands and jaw. He is a member of the [[International Boxing Hall of Fame]]. He was the [[Ring Magazine fighters of the year|''Ring Magazine'''s Fighter of the Year]] in 1929 and 1931.
